message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is caused by an immune response to an external allergen, and Th2 lymphocytes are involved in this response. Treg cells and Th1 cells have different functions in the immune system, and Kupffer cells are found in the liver and involved in immunity to pathogens in the blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is usually caused by an allergic reaction to environmental triggers such as pollen, dust mites, and animal dander. The immune response in extrinsic asthma involves the production of IgE antibodies, which activate Th2 lymphocytes to release inflammation-causing substances. Therefore, the increased quantities of Th2 lymphocytes would predispose the child to extrinsic asthma. Treg lymphocytes and Th1 lymphocytes are not involved in the pathogenesis of asthma, and Kupffer cells are liver macrophages and not relevant to asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is commonly caused by an allergic reaction to environmental triggers like dust, pollen, and animal dander. This type of asthma involves an immune response mediated by Th2 lymphocytes, which produce cytokines that stimulate inflammation and mucus production in the airways. Therefore, increased quantities of Th2 lymphocytes would predispose the child to extrinsic asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is also known as allergic asthma, meaning it is caused by an allergic reaction. Th2 lymphocytes are responsible for the production of allergen-specific immunoglobulin E (IgE) and the activation of eosinophils and mast cells, which are involved in the allergic response. Therefore, increased quantity of Th2 lymphocytes would predispose the child to extrinsic asthma. Treg lymphocytes are regulatory T cells that help to prevent autoimmune disease, Th1 lymphocytes are involved in cell-mediated immunity, and Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages in the liver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is associated with a type I hypersensitivity reaction to environmental allergens, which activate Th2 lymphocytes. Treg and Th1 lymphocytes are not associated with asthma. Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages found in the liver and are not directly involved in asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is triggered by environmental allergens, which usually result in an allergic response involving Th2 lymphocytes. Therefore, increased quantities of Th2 lymphocytes would predispose the child to extrinsic asthma. Treg lymphocytes and Th1 lymphocytes are involved in immunomodulation, while Kupffer cells are liver macrophages and not directly related to asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is associated with allergies and mediated by IgE antibodies, which are produced as a result of Th2 lymphocyte activation. Therefore, Th2 lymphocytes would predispose the child to extrinsic asthma. Treg lymphocytes help regulate the immune response and prevent autoimmunity, while Th1 lymphocytes mediate cell-mediated immunity. Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages found in the liver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is associated with Th2 lymphocytes, which are involved in the immune response to allergens. Treg lymphocytes are involved in suppression of the immune system, Th1 lymphocytes are involved in cellular immunity, and Kupffer cells are macrophages in the liver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is typically caused by IgE-mediated allergic reactions, which involve Th2 lymphocytes. Treg lymphocytes and Th1 lymphocytes are not involved in allergic reactions. Kupffer cells are found in the liver and have no direct involvement in asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Extrinsic asthma is caused by a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which involves Th2 lymphocytes. Therefore, increased quantities of Th2 lymphocytes would predispose the child to extrinsic asthma. Treg lymphocytes and Th1 lymphocytes are not involved in the pathogenesis of asthma. Kupffer cells are found in the liver and are not related to asthma.
